desc: Wesley Family Services' mission is to provide all children, adults, and families in need with transformational care. The CMU IS students redesigned the database schema and built a new web application to replace an existing client tracking software that was riddled with data loss and duplication issues. With this new application, call center staff will be able to more seamlessly and reliably enter client and inquiry details so that their clients can get access to the care they need without issues.

students: Miheer Lele, Jeffrey Chiu, Anant Agrawal
desc: The mission is to celebrate and share the joy of vegan food, connect vegans all around the world, and show how easy it is to start eating vegan. The students optimized the website by improving run time, working on search engine optimization, and reorganizing the information hierarchy. They also made improvements to user experience, through redesigning the site, standardizing the design, and connecting with social media.

students: June Sung Park, Sathya Hari, Nicasio Ng
desc: Medical Assistants are extremely important staff members who directly communicate with customers to provide healthcare services in both the lab and the office. The CMU IS students created an Onboarding Application, which consists of training modules that will aid Medical Assistants access the resources and training in an organized and logical manner as well as formalize the entire process of onboarding. This application was created to increase MA competency and content with their work.

students: Christopher Haas, Obi Nnaeto, Krishna Donepudi
desc: Our vision for this project involved a redesign of the website to promote professionalism and provide visitors with a more engaging experience along with the following additional pages: Conferences, Latest News, Events, and About Us pages. We also integrated the Events and Latest News pages with AAD's exisitng Facebook and Twitter accounts to help expand AAD's community engagemnet.

students: Mira Mookerjee, Justin Wang, Michael Cabral
desc: Amachi Pittsburgh's mission is to provide assistance for children of incarcerated parents. The CMU IS students implemented a complete redesign of the website, based on the pain points of various key stakeholder groups. The new design simplifies the user experience of the current website and makes it easier for different stakeholders to fulfill their needs, while exuding a brand that more closely matches how people see Amachi.

students: Eshita Banerjee, Ayaan Hussain, Grace Kim
desc: The Bloomfield-Garfield Corporation (BGC) exists to improve the quality of life for all in Garfield and surrounding neighborhoods through active community engagement with programs like the College and Career Readiness Program for high school students. We improved the processes involved with their database management system by consolidating and cleaning up the Google Sheets data and creating documentation for use cases on Salesforce that will allow our client to create useful reports. As a result of our work our client now has a new process of handling their new clean database and for creating reports easily so BGC can produce accurate reports to maintain or improve funding.

students: Claudia Osorio, Eric Liu, Joanna Miao
desc: Casa San Jose is a non-profit organization that seeks to strengthen and support the Latino community within the greater Pittsburgh area. The CMU IS students automated processes that the Casa San Jose staff did manually, and redesigned certain pages on the website. Staff now save significant amounts of time through this process automation.

students: Roy Xu, Jason Zhou, Daniel Li
desc: The Children's Institute of Pittsburgh is a non-profit organization dedicated to the special-needs children and their families in the Pittsburgh area. It is our team's goal to provide a modern and streamlined workflow for gathering signatures for the Children's Institute as it begins to digitize its many processes during this pandemic. Our team envisions a one-stop shop solution where the administrators at the Children's Institute can easily request signatures from patients and families, and check the progress of requests without having to go through a complicated onboarding process for any third-party providers.

students: Dennis Lo, Alec Oshita, Thomas Yager
desc: Computer Reach promotes technological literacy by providing refurbished equitment, computer literacy training, and support services to those who need it most. The CMU IS students integrated their POS software with their inventory management system. The result helped save staff many hours lost due to manually inputting transaction data into their inventory management system.

students: David Domalik, Sohan Kalva, Andy Park
desc: The mission of DCA is to increase Dietrich College's resources by establishing mutually-beneficial life-long relationships with alumni and organizational partners. The CMU IS students developed a website using the university CMS and implemented a process improvement with the integration of Salesforce's Web To Lead feature, making it nearly automatic to create new accurate entries in Salesforce. The main summative outcome is the growth of DCA's public presence used to increase the number of interested organizational partners.

students: Esteban Vázquez Cardona, JP Park, Leo Yao
desc: Fab Lab El Paso is a digital fabrication laboratory that provides services and programs in digital fabrication with the overall mission of promoting STEM education and digital fabrication in the region of El Paso, Texas. In line with those goals, the student team developed a Learning Management System that would allow the Fab Lab to provide online courses on digital fabrication and STEM for their community. Being able to provide online courses will increase the accessibility of STEM education and allow the Fab Lab to reach a greater audience.

students: Austin Leung, Mahima Shanware, Vivian Sun
desc: Greater Valley Community Services strengthens, educates, and empowers children and families through collaboration and resources within the Braddock Pittsburgh community. The CMU IS student team developed a database to simplify data reconciliation with the county for in-home crisis worker and family expenses. This helps GVCS staff by significantly reducing inaccuracies and overall time spent on identifying discrepancies with county invoices.

students: Blythe Weng, Shalini Rao, Max Dunaevschi
desc: The goal of this project was to improve data entry and inventory management, saving time and effort for the GWCFB staff and streamlining the reporting process for funding agencies. To accomplish this, the project aimed to reduce the number of human errors and improve efficiency in the data entry process for food donation and distribution. The solution was to find and document a new inventory management system to be implemented in place of their current accounting software. This includes a mobile application with scanning capability, as well as a website platform. Our stakeholders were the Greater Washington County Food Bank, its employees, the patrons that rely on the food bank, donors to the food bank, and volunteers. Our solution saves the organization time, limits human errors, and helps reduce food waste from untracked, expired donations.

students: Andy Chen, Matthew Fang, JJ Igims
desc: The mission statement of the Mon Metro Chamber of Commerce (MMCC) is to foster wealth in the community through education and capacity building by developing an equitable economic system of creativity, connectivity, and resource sharing. Our team created a website with a membership signup flow and membership directory, thereby providing a network for businesses to obtain resources to assist their businesses. Through this project, our team was able to help the MMCC turn their dreams into a tangible reality and bring them one step closer to achieving their vision of bringing economic prosperity to the Mon Metro region.

partner: Network of Academic Corporate Relations Officers (NACRO)
representatives: Kim Jacobs, Debbie Meyer, Jenna Brown
students: Shane Aung, Matt Cruz, Anmol Kapoor
desc: NACRO's mission is to promote best practices for corporate relations officers (CROs) with regards to building relationships and partnerships between universities and the industry. The CMU IS students merged their two main sites into a single integrated site with all of NACRO's content and functionality. The result was a more uniform user experience for both current and potential members, and the elimination of broken redirects as welll as login and privilege issues.

partner: The National Council of Jewish Women
students: Kat Phelps, Megan Naji, Sara Wong
desc: The National Council of Jewish Women (NCJW) is a grassroots organization of volunteers and advocates who turn progressive ideals into action. The CMU IS students built a website using Wix Events to help share information on events put on by NCJW. The result was a better system for viewing upcoming and past events and a system for displaying recorded Zoom sessions so anyone can view them.

students: Darren Kopa, Noah Yeo, Ron Chew
desc: NewERA412's mission is to increase the political equity and social capital of individuals who have experienced the Criminal Justice System, through an inclusive and diversified process of reintegration assistance and opportunities in Allegheny County. The CMU IS students improved upon a mobile responsive web application that allows street outreach workers keep track of returning citizens, refer multimedia and physical resources to them, and provides reports of the organization's activity in each neighborhood. The improvements to the application facilitated stronger engagement with returning citizens and easier reporting and accountability to the City of Pittsburgh.

students: David Cheung, Jonathan Monroe, Sebastian Yang
desc: PAPAFA aims to connect and provide resources to parents with children with mental or behavioral challenges. The CMU IS students helped reorganize their website and develop new pages to improve user experience, ability to find information, and membership value. We created five new pages that are now live on our client's website, and through our user testing, we significantly decreased the time it took for users to find critical information.

students: Ying Hu, Aiyana Huang, Jonathan Namovic
desc: The Persad Center offers care and counseling to the LGBTQ+ community aiming to improve their health and happiness. The CMU IS students created a centralized storage and automation flow that automatically inserts new survey responses to aggregated sheets. This helped Persad to gather all survey responses in one place automatically so they can access and analyze data efficiently.

students: Silvia Chen, Catherine Du, Isabella Fons
desc: The Piedmont Community Services Community Recovery Program, located in Martinsville, VA, helps support those with sustance abuse and/or mental health disorders recover and seek employment. The CMU IS students developed an online presence for the CRP, including a website, social media strategy, and referral process. The online presence allows CRP to further their outreach and accessibility within the community, especially among a younger demographic.

students: Preethi Surapaneni, Evan Zeng, Lexie Rodriguez
desc: Plaza Pittsburgh, as a branch of Presente Pittsburgh, has a mission to share resources with Latinos, empower their community, and elevate the quality of life of Hispanics in the region. The CMU IS student team created a business directory website where Latinos can search for resources and local businesses. Latinos in Pittsburgh will have the ability to find Spanish speaking businesses that fit their needs.

students: Caitlin Huang, David Yuan, Kevin Wang
desc: Red Cloud Indian School is a catholic institution that has been taken care of by the Jesuits and Lakota people for over 125 years. The school has been able to successfully immerse students in the Lakota language within classroom lessons, but since it is a minority language, it is barely represented in any of their technology. The student team explored different avenues from open-source educational games, interactive storytelling platforms, and created a way to represent Lakota language through the game Minecraft. They also reached out to the game developer suggesting Lakota language be added to the game.

students: Matt Buchman, Shwetha Shinju, Bennett Huffman
desc: We planned to clarify and streamline the current STTE app's primary function of helping students and aspiring entrepreneurs evaluate and explore their ideas—making the ideation phase of the entrepreneurial process fun and engaging.

students: Alex Bellomo, Joyce Wu, Rjay Lane
desc: This Is Laisa, LLC's mission is to strive to give students the resources they need to succeed academically, and level the playing field by ensuring access for all. Our team built a front-end that connects students who have school projects with financial needs to sponsors who would be willing to donate money to that student's project, and designed the front-end to be accessible to many user groups, so that any student, regardless of disabilities, will be able to use the platform to find a sponsor for their project. The result of our efforts is a fully accessible web application that the client can easily deploy or extend.

students: Andey Ng, Jonthan Fischer, Phil Huang
desc: Virginia Dere is a Black-owned, Women-owned startup whose mission is to enable women to feel empowered to swim through fashionable, modest swimwear to ultimately look how they feel. The CMU IS team worked with the client to improve her technology infrastructure and management, particularly the design and structure of her websites: the KneeKini product website and the Virginia Dere corporate website. The team improved the user experience through a redesign and restructuring of the websites. Moreover, the client is able to edit the websites to add information about new products, styles, and vendors, and/or incorporate additional functionality to the site.

students: Abhi Devarapalli, Jeff Xu, Raymond Li
desc: The mission of Wesley Family Services is 'To empower children, adults, and families by providing transformational care'. The project team used c# on dotnet core to implement a web-based database application that improves on the current application being used to keep track of Wesley clients and their inquiries. The result is a more user-friendly, data-normalized, and easier-maintained application that plans to be deployed by the end of the summer of 2021.

students: Christine Kim, Ricky Ma, Gabriela Tellez
desc: Western Pennsylvania Bible Quizzing is a ministry dedicated to encouraging young children and teens to learn scripture from the Bible in a competitive and fun way in Western Pennsylvania districts. The CMU IS student team updated the organization's Quiz Generator application, developed an API for the application, and created a central website for the organization. These solutions will benefit the sustainability of the organization by providing ease for future development and maintenance of the Quiz Generator, in addition to engaging stakeholders of the organization through the central site.

partner: Western Pennsylvania School for the Deaf
students: Alex Chen, Ankita Kundu, Lily Huang
desc: The Western Pennsylvania's School for the Deaf's affiliate program Choices for Children is an early intervention program supporting parents of deaf or hard-of-hearing newborns by teaching them how to raise their child. The CMU IS students developed a website for this program, serving as a resource bank for parents to garner accurate information on CFC and deaf or hard-of-hearing children. The website was set up on the new CFC domain, increasing the online presence of CFC and information availability on deaf and hard-of-hearing children.

students: Ananya Bhat, Daniel Ng, Daphne Yang
desc: Women Against Abusive Relationships (WAAR) is a nonprofit organization devoted to the awareness, education, and prevention of violence against women and girls, founded and directed by Roxanne Epperson. The goal of the CMU IS team was to build a new WordPress website and have it serve as a central hub for information on WAAR, their resources, and the services they provide in order to help raise exposure beyond Pittsburgh and make opportunities to heal more accessible for victims and survivors of abusive relationships. The new website has a more streamlined navigation, and allows for users to create accounts, listen to WAAR's podcast episodes, and watch their previous panel discussions, thus increasing the opportunities for community members to engage with WAAR.

representatives: Anna Hollis, Nicole Cannon, Samantha Monks
students: Doug Heymann, Philip Wellener, Zeke Rong
desc: Amachi Pittsburgh's mission is to empower and support youth with incarcerated parents in the local community. The CMU IS student team improved their online presence through a two-pronged approach that includes improving their search engines optimization and user experience. This enables Amachi to reach a larger audience and better support their current clients.

students: Luke Arney, Andrew Butler, Simran Virdi
desc: Assemble Pittsburgh is a non-profit organization dedicated to helping individuals grow in STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, and Math) fields by hosting many programs for all ages. Located in the Garfield neighborhood of Pittsburgh they aim to serve the local community. The student team designed a solution called ClassDojo to solve the problem of tracking a student's work. Teachers upload student work which allows parents to view their child's growth and showcases the student's work. Teachers keep track of student progress which aids them in developing future lesson plans and activities.

students: Rohit Kumar, Ayoub Mansar, Matthew Guo
desc: The Bhutanese Community Association of Pittsburgh's mission is “To ensure a high quality of life for all members of the Bhutanese community in Pittsburgh and to support their integration into American Society through culturally-informed services and activities.” The CMU IS student team created an online web app that helps BCAP better track, view, and record their volunteers' information and events hosted. This web app significantly saves time for all BCAP staff in dealing with volunteer information, helps reduce the chances of errors with the data, and enables BCAP to better use the data in their various needs.

partner: Center for Organ Recovery and Education
representatives: Bruno Mastroianni, Colleen Sullivan, Bill DiPlacido, Edward Horne, David Hoss, Katelynn Metz
students: Anthony Lees, Ethan Nankervis, Emily Zhang
desc: The Center for Organ Recovery & Education (CORE) is an organ procurement organization based out of Pittsburgh. They work to find donors for organs and service nearly 6 million people across 155 hospitals. The student team automated the legal next of kin and donor information submission and event registration process for the “A Special Place” honorary donor ceremony. With this Wordpress web application, CORE staff was able to eliminate errors in data entry, create a single source of donor and next of kin data and streamline the event registration process.

students: Jimmy Zeng, Susan Song, Tyler Lowe
desc: Computer Reach is a nonprofit organization that focuses on providing technological access to those left behind in the digital revolution. Together with Kyle Spangler and David Mitchell, we worked to develop an automated volunteer sign-in system using Salesforce Flows. Our project reduced check-in time by 90%, had zero running cost, and achieved sustainability by building technological capacity internally.

partner: Dietrich College Dean's Office of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion
students: Neha Choudhari, Gloria Moon, Augustus Saalfeld
desc: The Dietrich College Dean's Office of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion aims to cultivate diverse perspectives and promote equity and inclusion. The CMU IS student team interviewed stakeholders, defined the problem space, and streamlined the data collection process through a Google Form and Tableau Dashboard. This helps the client by solving the lack of communication issues, saving time, and measuring the impact and success of DEI efforts.

representatives: David Palmer, Tim Daigle, Kim Reed
students: Kieran Walsh, Emily Feng, Grace Joseph
desc: Redemption-Driven Exchange (RDX) is a nonprofit startup founded by faith-driven entrepreneurs that wish to provide an empowering package for other entrepreneurs from all communities to succeed through mentorship. The CMU IS students helped bring RDX's vision to life by spending this semester building a proof-of-concept platform where Christian entrepreneurs can match with mentors based on their needs and the mentor's experience.

students: Navid Mamoon, Riccardo Santoni, Helena Spencer
desc: First Tee Pittsburgh is a youth development program focused on impacting the lives of young people by providing educational programs that build character, instill life-enhancing values, and promote healthy choices through the game of golf. The CMU IS team developed a server-side automation process that streamlined the scheduling process for coaches as well as improved the communication between coaches and guardians of participants.

representatives: Jackie Smith, Tempestt Henderson, Brady Lefkowitz
students: Kenny Hu, Harriet Khang, Rebecca Li
desc: GVCS serves to strengthen, educate, and empower children and families through collaboration and resources. The CMU IS students developed organizational boards that automated and digitized many tasks. This helped streamline and organize GVCS into a more tech-savvy organization.

representatives: Jon Schubert, Cherise Sandrock, Justin McAtee
students: Nina Li, Dee Harris, John Namgung
desc: Food Helpers is Washington County's leader for helping those who are fighting against hunger. To help streamline the food assistance experience, we developed a mobile application that provides user-relevant information presented in a digestible format and simplified food program registrations.  This approach of providing a mobile application uniquely serves numerous users with limited access to computers or WiFi and builds a foundation for the Food Helpers to migrate their other services onto mobile devices.

students: Sabrina Chua, Jonathan Nottingham, Megan Qiang
desc: The International Free Expression Project (IFEP) aims to promote the creation of the arts and lift voices that are suppressed by governments and political extremists around the world by providing performance spaces, funding, and educational materials to artists and the public. The CMU IS students researched, selected, and implemented a third-party CRM system which can now serve as a centralized place to manage constituent information and interactions, and to automate tasks pertaining to donation processing and email communication. The CRM reduces the time and effort required from staff for managing these activites, while increasing constituent engagement with IFEP and the outputs of any fundraising efforts.

students: Thomas Choi, Roshan Ram, Brian Chou
desc: KidsVoice is a nonprofit legal agency that represents abused, neglected, and at-risk children, up to the age of 24. The CMU IS team created a database and data migration solution that is able automate the process of tracking clients and their relevant cases. This project helps save KidsVoice 5-7 hours per week.

students: Anjali Akula, Takho Lee, Kate Zhao
desc: The mission of the Learning Disabilities Association is to create opportunities for success for all individuals affected by learning disabilities through support, education, and advocacy . The CMU IS students created a data repository to aggregate learning disability resources including therapists, psychiatrists and tutors. The result was a centralized location with over 1000 resources for people with learning disabilities and improved efficiency for finding resources that fit multiple constraints such as price, location and budget,

students: Gautam Kapoor, Phi Nguyen, Xinda Zhou
desc: The Mon Metro Chamber of Commerce (MMCC), located in the Braddock/East Pittsburgh region, is a neighborhood hub of connection, resources, skill building, and partnership with a mission of economic development for all. Our team developed a backend database infrastructure on the chamber's website to allow them to better store their members' information and understand what services their members want to see. With this, the chamber will be able to offer more targeted services to the communities they aim to serve and bring them closer to achieving their goal of bringing economic success to the Mon Metro region.

students: Stella Yan, Sara Missak, Chanaradee Leelamanthep
desc: The organization's mission is to raise money to help to step forward, speak out, and stand up for the needs of women, children, and families. They have faith in the future and a belief in action. The CMU IS team integrated tools and documentation in order to increase the businesses' efficiency and long term sales.

students: Ruitao Li, Vishnu Pathmanaban, Karen Wu
desc: NewEra412's mission is to provide reintegration assistance and opportunties to all members of Allegheny county. Our team expanded the regions covered in the application, implemented the ability to add organizations, created an organization supervisor view to manage organization data, and implemented a feature to download data with analytics from a specific time period. The project improved the applications scalability, increasing the ability to process an increase in partnered organizations, outreach workers, and data.

students: Ivana Lin, Oliver Lance, Sean Tavares
desc: One to World is a non-profit organization from New York working to build face-to-face experiences among local communities, international students and Fulbright scholars. The CMU IS students created a step by step process that defined the timeline of how students are involved with One To World and how that timeline of engagement can be extended as students transition to alumni. This helped One To World leverage past student data and improve their current data collection process so that they can reach out to alumni and engage with a previously untapped community by inviting them to volunteer, attend events, promote their experiences with One To World and essentially help drive the continuation and growth of their organization.

students: Kalen Gressler, Siddharth Paratkar, Max Sobkov
desc: Patchy Fog spreads outdoor, self guided education to get those who may normally be glued to their computers, out of the house. The CMU IS team is helping to spread the project further from the initial school district where it was implemented by building a virtual community for social interaction and collaboration, as well as a webapp to submit and view the products of community members.

representatives: Lezetta Cox, Allison Haley, Jennie Pabst, Emily Wilton
students: Jaclyn Yang, Ruilin Feng, Stephanie Tseng
desc: Peoples Oakland, is an organization focusing on the rehabilitation and recovery of its members, many of whom have some sort of a chronic mental illness. The CMU IS students implemented a complete redesign of Peoples Oakland site to address the painpoints of Peoples Oakland's members and web admin. The redesigned website significantly improves the user experience and addresses the needs of more stakeholders (members, providers, and supporters) while making the backend processes for the web admin more efficient.

students: Neha Chintamaneni, Cecilia Mendoza, Govind Menon
desc: Pennsylvania Resources Council (PRC) is Pennsylvania's oldest grassroots environmental organization. The CMU IS students developed standardized Excel data templates for each program in addition to summary statistics. The templates were used by program directors to create grant reports and annual reports.

students: Allison Cao, Waverly Chin, Sara Song
desc: The Queens Gamit Chess Institute's mission is to provide enrichment chess classes to under served communities in the greater Pittsburgh area. The CMU IS developed a CRM wesbite using Ruby on Rails for TQGCI to better manage community partnerships and programs.

students: Mikail Cheema, Vishesh Pagarani, Neha Joshi
desc: Our vision for this engagement was to modernize Lakota by increasing its representation in technology. In order to do this, we explored many different avenues from open-source educational games, interactive storytelling platforms, and through Minecraft.

partner: Saint Sebastian Center for Performance Excellence
students: Hita Kambhamettu, Leanne Sun, Alexander Chiu
desc: Saint Sebastian Center is an organization that specializes in providing mental coaching to athletes and performing artists. The CMU IS team provided a Wordpress-hosted website to our client in order to solve the problem of not having a cohesive platform for hosting online content and information on the website. This added immense value in establishing an online presence for the company.

students: Sooyoung Kim, Sung Tae Kim, Tina Lin
desc: SHIM wants to create an inclusive community where everyone has the opportunity to thrive. The CMU IS students created an app that allows volunteers and donors to receive notifications and view events they can participate in. This will increase the efficiency of how SHIM serves the South Hills community.

students: Luye Zhou, Cheng Ma, Isaac Ahn
desc: STTE's mission is to develop and deploy entrepreneurship and/or STEM-based educational programs and resources for both students and adults to advance economic development. We built a program that scans a user generated crossword puzzle, detects valid climate change related terminology, and dynamically generates a public webpage of content related to the terminology detected. The project will improve climate change related education by providing a gamified and interactive exhibit for K-12 students to learn about climate change, as well as enable STTE to demo this exhibit to other museums that may be interested in a creating a climate change related exhibit.

students: Anagha Srikumar, Tim Wang, Varshaa SJ
desc: The Children's Home of Pittsburgh is an independent, non-profit, licensed organization whose mission is to promote the health and wellbeing of infants and children through services that establish and strengthen the family. The CMU IS student team digitized the breast-milk verification and inventory tracking system. This system helps streamline the bottle check in and checkout processes, saves paperwork from the old manual process, and reduces human error by delegating calculations to the technology.

students: Maya Pandurangan, Scott King, Shayan Panjwani
desc: The Primate Portal at the Seneca Park Zoo in Upstate NY is a research and STEM outreach project that provides interdisciplinary science experiences for children and adults. The public zoo exhibit allows visitors to watch olive baboons solve cognitive problems presented as computerized tasks on a touchscreen. The CMU IS student team integrated and automated the submission of elementary student scratch code, the translation of the code to the touchscreen for the baboons to interact with and the presentation of livestream video of the baboons to youtube. This greatly expands the outreach and allows students to observe baboons interacting with their code, increasing student interest in biology, psychology and computer science.

students: Nithin Ravi, April Wu, Kyle Yang
desc: Wesley Family Services (WFS) is composed of a group of talented individuals who are dedicated to one common mission: “...to empower children, adults, and families through transformational care”. For this project, the students of CMU IS students created an internal alert system that will streamline the emergency communication protocol, which was highly time costly, and prevent wasted employee time and man power. With this internal alert system, all impacted individuals can get notified in a timely manner and prevent any avoidable losses.

students: Amy Luo, Sophy Peng, Divya Viswanathan
desc: When She Thrives is an organization supporting single mothers through assistive resources and programs to empower them. CMU IS students developed a client-management dashboard where admins can efficiently view and modify client information to better track and address each individual's needs efficiently and a user-friendly data dashboard providing reminders to follow up with clients, and create meaningful demographic reports.

students: Atah Okaisabor, Deekshita Vedula, Sihan Wu
desc: WAAR's mission is to break the cycle of violence against women and girls and aid in their healing process. The CMU IS team expanded WAAR's website to include a survey for members to share their journeys with others, and a filterable shelter locator, providing important resources to domestic abuse victims in one place for quicker access.

representatives: Sera Linardi, Ivy Chang, Leo Jung
students: Danagul Azimzhanova, Jacky He, Kevin Lin, Eric Rohrer
desc: 412Connect aims to showcase organizations from marginalized communities to local university students through an online scavenger hunt. The CMU IS student team primarily worked on addressing the current pain points of the website by redesigning the user dashboard, revamping the user authentication process, and remodeling user feedback collection. These changes should create a more intuitive user experience that helps the platform better retain students down the line.

students: Saloni Gandhi, Kimberly Gao, Zhuowen (Helen) Huang, Zahir Saiyed
desc: Amachi Pittsburgh is a non-profit organization dedicated to empowering, nurturing, and protecting youth affected by incarceration in the Greater Pittsburgh area through mentoring programs. The CMU IS students developed a communication platform on Geneva to build a community for Amachi's mentors, providing a range of support resources. This initiative fosters a sense of community among mentors and streamlines communication between staff and mentors, ultimately contributing to more effective mentorship and improved outcomes for the youth involved.

students: Adriana Poznanski, Mona Lin, Marko Henien, Rahul Ravula
desc: The mission of BCAP is to provide support, education and a sense of community for Bhutanese community members in Pittsburgh. Our consulting team helped BCAP centralize their information management, and implement an appointment management system using Google Suite. This solution will help BCAP spend less time tracking down information, and more time meeting with community members, which further promotes the organization's mission.

students: Jim Chen, Rebecca Jiang, Anna Li, Victor Waddell
desc: Center for Organ Recovery & Education's mission is to save and heal lives through donation. The CMU IS students created a custom web app for more systematic event management. The result was automated the event management process, improved efficiency, reduced human error, and facilitated donation education.

students: Pranav Addepalli, David Matovic, Sean Pham, Dillon Shu
desc: The Center for Shared Prosperity aims to reduce structural barriers to equitable prosperity in the Pittsburgh region. In order to help achieve this, the CMU IS student team created a website to showcase local minoritized businesses to students and also made a process document that covers how to host a local business on campus. Both of these deliverables are part of an initiative to increase CMU engagement with local businesses, both in terms of awareness and spending.

students: Brandan Chen, Elyse Im, Joanna Yao
desc: Computer Reach's mission is to make technology available to people most in need through refurbished equipment, computer literacy, training, and support. The CMU IS student team developed a Python script to automate the device data collection and upload process of incoming machines donated to the organization. With this script, Computer Reach is able to improve productivity, save time and effort. as well as minimize errors from manual data entry.

students: Asyer Yonas, Joan Lee, Tejas Venkatesh, Wenshan Jiang
desc: Equity Impact Center's vision is to trasnform leaders, non-profits and the arts to be a means through which we develop a more equitable society. Our project worked to create an online portal where volunteers and non-profits can easily find and connect with each other. This would generate more volunteering hours in the community and allow EIC's partners to be able to better fill volunteer positions.

students: Lea De Vylder, Michelle Liu, Alex Barrios
desc: The Filipino-American Association of Pittsburgh's mission is to preserve, promote, and perpetuate the Filipino heritage among its members and the general public through cultural, charitable, and educational activities. The CMU IS students improved their data management due to their lack of centralization and automation. The result was an improved website with automated data collection and transfer of legacy data into their new system.

students: Edward Chen, Alexander Ma, Nathan Maher
desc: Often, First Tee coaches need to cancel classes in case of emergencies and notify the participants as soon as possible, which can take quite a bit of time out in the field. The mission was to create a user friendly application that allows First Tee coaches to send mass text and mass email notifications to participants in their classes in case of emergencies or cancellations in the click of just a few buttons.

students: Jasmine Nie, Ryan McGrady, Annie Eng
desc: We wish to set up a Ruby on Rails web application hosted on GitHub that enables secure digital submission of documents from foster parents with caseworkers who will be able to add checklist categories for foster parents to complete. The CMU IS team created a Ruby on Rails app that was deployable on a non static website that allows case workers and foster care parents to submit documents and view when they're due. The impact of the project allowed the organization to make file organization / collection faster and streamlined through converting to digital forms.

students: Emma Kwan, Meghana Tera, Ricky Lee, Yize Shen
desc: The Greater Washington County Food Bank's mission is to help those who are fighting against hunger. The CMU IS students' role is to help standardize the onboarding process for volunteers and incoming staff. The result was an improved understanding of the food bank's CRM for both staff and volunteers.

students: Julia Graham, Miles Maltbia, Maddie Thai-Tang, Zach Van Bennekum
desc: Hello Neighbor is a non-profit organization working to improve the lives of recently resettled refugee and immigrant families by matching them with dedicated neighbors to guide and support them in their new lives. The team of CMU IS students developed a cleaner and more robust system for managing the inflow and outflow of donations to Hello Neighbor and its clients. This system provides cleaner and more accurate information with less manual work, allowing the team at Hello Neighbor to spend more time out in the field working directly with clients.

representatives: Shannon Dickerson, Kayla Seifert, Sabrina Culyba
students: Esther Bae, Anita Cheng, Richelle Guice, Emily Zhang
desc: Humane Action Pittsburgh (HAP) is a nonprofit organization based in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania that works with the Pittsburgh community to advocate for animal welfare and climate change. The CMU IS student team created a search feature for HAP's campain ReimagineTakeout, allowing users to see if a takeout item is compostable and if so, how to properly compost the item.

students: Jenny Doan, Katie Lin, Nicole Xiang
desc: The International Free Expression Project (IFEP) aims to democratize art and removing barriers to free expression by showcasing the work of artists whose voices have been suppressed via a virtual gallery. The CMU IS students researched, interviewed, and designed the virtual gallery, which will help artists display their work from around the world. The virtual gallery design gives artists a channel for community, connection, and support, where they will be able to share their voice through art.

students: Anesha Santhanam, Emily Ngo, Fernanda Molina, Valeria Cordova
desc: JADA House International uplifts the Hazelwood and Greater Pittsburgh community by providing an inclusive physical space where teens, senior citizens, and families can build positive relationships within their community and strengthen their social, emotional, and spiritual lives. The CMU IS students developed and redesigned the organizations' current website to enhance community engagement, increase communication, and attract more donors while taking advantage of website analytics to better serve their community. The impact of our project is expected to attract new members and donors while effectively advertising programs and services to serve more individuals in need.

representatives: Tom Welschonce, Tara GainfoTom Welschonce & Tara Gainfort
students: Amita Goyal, Amanda Jin, Steven Zhang
desc: KidsVoice is a nonprofit legal agency that represents abused, neglected, and at-risk children, up to the age of 24. The CMU IS team improved the accuracy of the data sorting process for the existing database management system and created a user interface to simplify the data migration pipeline. In addition, the CMU IS team expanded the database functionality by creating queries to display changes in between data pulls, such that the KidsVoice team can easily identify updates to client records.This project helps save KidsVoice time and resources.

students: Keerthana Vinay, Megan Lin, Nathan Oswell
desc: The Learning Disabilities Association of Pennsylvania aims to promote and support the education and general welfare of individuals with learning and attention issues and their families. As a team, we built a comprehensive search directory that would help LDA of PA efficiently share information about service providers and learning disabilities. Our solution allows users to easily find the resources they need to effectively navigate learning disabilities.

representatives: Shannan Katanick, Carol Lawson, Melany Alliston, Katie Whitney, Colleen Fedor
students: Ziqi Ding, Yewon Lee, Spencer Long
desc: Munhall CARES' mission is to provide volunteer support to enrich our community through service and events. The CMU IS student team redeveloped their ground-level website by improving the website UI for accessibility and usability, and embedding Google Calendars and Google Forms for organization of event information and logistics. This enabled Munhall CARES to reach more residents and make the community more integrated together. Additionally, it also brings an accessible and streamlined method for Munhall Cares Board Members to track event logistics.

students: Zhijie Gao, Julia Hou, Cara Savoy, Kevin Wu
desc: Neighborhood Learning Alliance is a nonprofit organization that strives to improve education and opportunities of lower-income families within Allegheny County, offering multiple programs for students from kindergarten through high school that focus on supplementary learning as well as higher education. The CMU IS team redesigned their website in order to provide more resources to their community as well as provide a central hub of information about the organization to streamline communication and outreach.

students: Mahith Edula, Neel Mandapati, Zexuan Li, Ziyan Wang
desc: New Sun Rising (NSR) is a nonprofit organization that organizes and supports community development initiatives within Pittsburgh, with the mission 'Build vibrant communities through culture, sustainability, and opportunity'. The CMU IS students worked with New Sun Rising to create a digital form to collect contextual data (opinions/fears/hopes) of members of a community and store it within their database. This will add value by giving additional information to properly understand problems local Pittsburgh communities are facing.

students: Leah Walko, Melody Zhang, Emma-Miranda Herrera
desc: The mission is to advance global cooperation by fostering intercultural interactions and learning. The CMU IS students created a Wix site and database the Global Classroom team members will use. The result was an improved onboarding experience for Global guides and a more efficient process of collecting and accessing data in a centralized place for the One To World team.

students: Annie Wu, Dora Xiao, Rohan Butani
desc: NewEra412 is the information management system for the city of Pittsburgh's violence prevention initiatives. The CMU IS student team commissioned the best software development partner for NewEra412, fixed bugs, and designed new features. Now NewEra412 can focus on sustained growth and longevity with a solid vision and the support to back it up.

students: Emma Jiang, Ruoxi Yang, Jennifer Zhang
desc: Pittsburghers for Public Transit (PPT) is a transit rider and worker-led organization working towards creating a better transit system in Pittsburgh. When it comes to Pittsburgh citizens that do not follow active campaigns for transit justice, PPT relies on its website to both spread awareness about the program and gain insight into peoples' experiences with public transportation. The student team improved the following components of the website: 1) SEO and accessibility improvements based on feedback from PPT members with sensory impairments, 2) a call to action in the form of a newsletter sign-up form embedded into the website and integrated with EveryAction, and 3) integrating the events calendar on EveryAction into the live website.

students: Vatsalya Verma, Woojoo Lee, Massa Coulibaly, Joanne Tsai
desc: Pittsburgh Lutheran United Ministries (PLUM) is a unique and innovative community service provider that brings together ten Lutheran congregations in the greater Pittsburgh area. The CMU IS students implemented a Google ecosystem for storing data securely, managing files effectively, and managing various schedules for pastoral care events.

students: Alice Hong, Samiul Hoque, Sunny Liang
desc: Kingdom Adventures is a Christian non-profit whose mission is to empower under-privileged youth in the Philippines through educational programs. The CMU student team created a well-documented open-source web application that allows users to read the Bible as well as write and respond to commentary on each Bible verse from other users. Using this, the Filipino students under Project Mustard Seed's educational program will be inspired to learn how to code and be able to contribute to their first open-source software project.

students: Brianna Wang, Erica Fu, Victoria Zhang
desc: Project Theia's mission is to provide oculoplastic medical and surgical care to the underserved global community. The CMU IS students furthered this mission by enhancing remote communication with all of their Global Providers, preparing Project Theia to scale. The team utilized Slack to centralize communication, organize educational resources, and support effective remote communication.

representatives: Chelsea Buell, Jim Cirilano, Gillian Graber
students: Clara Lam, Jason Perez, Michael Song
desc: Protect Penn-Trafford (Protect PT) is committed to protecting Penn-Trafford and surrounding communities from the harmful environmental effects of energy projects through education and legal advocacy. The CMU IS students developed a web application with functionality to allow data entry and retrieval of information related to energy projects. The web application was used as a working prototype to demonstrate to potential funders the potential of this system.

students: Angela Chen, Saaatvik Korisepati, Lisa Leung, Emmeline Wetzel
desc: Queens Gambit is an organization that aims to empower youth through chess, especially those who are underrepresented in the chess community. The team implemented two solutions for Queens Gambit: a new online tournament pairing system and updating their community partner relationship management system. As a result, Queens Gambit is able to run their classes and tournaments more effectively and manage their partner data in a more organized manner.

students: Anna Rippert, Cami Wu, Daniel Arriola
desc: The mission of The Italian Garden Project is to celebrate the joy and wisdom inherent in the traditional Italian American vegetable garden, preserving this heritage and demonstrating its relevance for reconnecting to our food, our families and the earth. The CMU IS students created The Legacy Fig Tree Archive website that allows individuals to enter their fig tree into the archive and search the database for the fig trees. The archive demonstrates the prevalence of the fig growing tradition throughout the US and creates a sense of community for fig tree owners.

partner: The Way Community Center of Greene County
students: Fu Hao Wei, Bernard Sheng, He Yucheng
desc: The Way Community Center of Greene County is a non-profit organization located in Waynesburg, Pennsylvania dedicated to promoting education, fostering relationships, and creating a safe and supportive environment for all members of the community. Our team's project automates the data collection and processing for the Community Development Block Grant Survey and provide monitoring of the demographics of participants who benefit from their programs. Our impact is hopefully to get the developmental grant approved for our client.

students: Mitun Adenuga, Fiona Chiu, Ayush Tripathi
desc: Wesley Family Services is a non-profit organization that caters to individuals who lack the resources to find care on their own. Together with the senior IT head at Wesley Family Services, Aaron Richards, we are working to automate the process of account creation to reduce the manual labor required in the new employee onboarding process. We are striving to unify the automation process through a central database that tracks the status of each account. Our solution adds value by shortening the onboarding process from 3 days to 4 hours and frees up employees with higher-level skills to work on more complicated tasks.

students: Amy Deng, Cathryn Lin, Lucy Li
desc: Women Against Abusive Relationships (WAAR) is a Pittsburgh-based volunteer organization that aims to break the cycle of domestic violence by providing education, awareness, and prevention programs, directed by Roxanne Epperson. The CMU IS student team revamped the website to meet ADA compliance, and restructured the information architecture to optimize usability, to help users find the resources they need quickly and efficiently.

representatives: Ousmane Kabré, Abigail Boateng Gyasi, Brandi Kochera
students: Tobi Adisa, Gabriella Ardiles, Simon Corpuz, Rachel Martini
desc: Yam Education enhances students' learning experiences in higher education by making it accessible anywhere, at any time, through their virtual educational platform and partnerships with U.S.-based educational institutions. The CMU IS student team implemented Classter, a Student Information Management System, to not only streamline Yam's admissions process, but create a centralized channel of communication and implement advising capabilities that will foster strong relationships between students and advisors. Classter will play a pivotal role in ensuring efficient, streamlined admissions and advising processes in Yam Education's full pilot rollout during the summer of 2023.

students: Colin May, Nathan Wai, Daniel Gunawan
desc: Youth Enrichment Services (YES) aims to empower socially and economically at-risk youth to achieve success through academic preparation, career exploration, and cultural and social leadership development. The CMU IS student team developed a mobile and web application to streamline the arduous SMS communication process with YES students, which was previously time-intensive and constrained staff capacity. With this automated communication system, all YES students can get notified about events in a timely manner while improving YES' capacity for student enrichment.
